Well. To see the lightbeam, the light has to hit the camera sensor, or your eye.
You see the catch 22 there, don't you?

However. There is something similar that has been filmed.
A very short burst of light hitting an object has been filmed with an extremely high fps camera. It's on Youtube. Just search for it: "Light in Slow Motion"

MIT produced a camera that can film at a trillion FPS.

/watch?v=EtsXgODHMWk
Sol; it's possible, and requires a pretty fast camera:  /watch?v=snSIRJ2brEk

Light travels at around 186,000 miles in a vacuum. And it takes around 500 seconds for the light from the sun to reach Earth after it's been emitted. I don't believe we have a camera that can record even a beam of light once it's emitted from something like a spotlight.

There's no such thing as 'sterile enough'.  Either something is sterile or it isn't.  There's no gradation.

Not that I care, really, just pointing out a minor inaccuracy.

"In times of war, when other antiseptics were unavailable, urine, the darker the better, was utilized on open wounds as an antibacterial"

No, and the flaw in that isn't to do with the speed of light. First you need to properly understand what it is to "see something", so when you see something like a red shirt, what is really happening is that light previously hit the shirt, got absorbed and the shirt emitted red light, this red light entered your eye and behold, you saw a red shirt.

With light that doesn't work, you can't see any light that doesn't enter your eye and light doesn't carry any information (color) about other light.
